questions.text:
The diagnosis for a 23-year-old patient presenting with non-scarring alopecia in the vertex region of the head, and exhibiting histological findings of hair loss with haemorrhage into the follicular areas and mild perinuclear lymphocytic infiltrate, is what? 
(AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trichotillomania

 

From the given clinical features & histopathological features, diagnosis is Trichotillomania (TTM) / Trichotillosis / Hair pulling disorder.

 

Clinical features suggestive of Trichotillomania in the clinical vignette:

 

  • The clinical history revealing non scarring alopecia in the vertex region (Hair pulling and plucking is commonest from the scalp)
  • No signs of inflammation
  • Perifollicular hemorrhage

 

Diagnostic criteria for TTM include:

 

  • Recurrent pulling out of one’s own hair resulting in non-scarring hair loss.
  • An increasing sense of tension immediately before pulling out the hair or when attempting to resist the behaviour.
  • Pleasure, gratification, or relief when pulling out the hair.
  • The disturbance is not better accounted for by another mental disorder.
  • The disturbance provokes clinically marked distress and/or impairment in occupational, social, or other areas of functioning.
  • Histopathology: No / Minimal inflammation
  • Peribulbar hemorrhage - due to trauma from plucking of hair.
  • intraepithelial and perifollicular hemorrhage and intrafollicular pigment casts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alopecia areata:

 

  • While it is characterized by non-scarring alopecia and can have lymphocytic infiltrate around the hair follicles, the hemorrhage is not a typical feature.
  • Generally presents as well-defined patches of hair loss.

 

Option B. Telogen effluvium:

 

  • It manifests as a diffuse or generalized hair shedding from the entire scalp rather than localized patches.
  • It's commonly due to stress, certain medications, or illnesses.
  • Histopathology would not typically show hemorrhage or the specific perinuclear infiltrate described.

 

Option C. Tinea infection:

 

  • Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp.
  • It usually presents with scaling and possibly broken-off hairs.
  • Histological examination would show evidence of fungal elements (hyphae and spores) rather than hemorrhage or lymphocytic infiltrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young patient with non-scarring alopecia in the vertex region and histological findings of hair loss with follicular hemorrhage and mild lymphocytic infiltrate, the diagnosis is likely Trichotillomania.

 

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 86 & 89, page nos 86.17 & 89.31

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page no: 1695

questions.text: A young woman presents with complaints of a painless ulcer in the genital area. It is associated with non-tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Syphilis

 

Given scenario points out to a diagnosis of syphilis

 

ACQUIRED SYPHILIS:

 

Mode of acquisition - Sexual transmission & Blood transfusion

 

Stages are as follows –

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chancroid: In this condition both genital ulcer and inguinal lymphadenopathy are painful. It is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi, with an incubation period of 2-5 days.

 

 

Option C. Herpes genitalis: It causes painful ulcers in the genital region and localized tender lymphadenopathy, caused by HSV 2 > 1.

 

 

Option D. Granuloma inguinale (aka donovanosis): It is caused by the bacterium Calymmatobacter / Klebsiella granulomatis. There is NO pain in Ulcer & NO Lymphadenopathy

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary syphilis (syphiLESS) is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a Painless genital ulcer and Painless inguinal lymphadenopathy, which are classic presentations of this sexually transmitted infection.

 

References: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page no: 28.8-29, 29.13-16

Jawetz Melnick & Adelbergs Medical Microbiology 28th edition Page no 339, 341, 342

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 379-383

questions.text: A patient presents with annular lesions on the skin. Which of the following conditions is least likely to present with annular lesions? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urticaria

 

Explanation:

 

Urticaria, commonly known as hives, is characterized by transient, well-circumscribed, erythematous, and edematous plaques that can be pruritic.

 

 

These lesions typically appear and disappear within a few hours and do not usually form annular (ring-shaped) patterns. Urticaria can be triggered by various factors including allergens, stress, or physical stimuli, but the lesions themselves are generally not annular.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tinea corporis: This is a dermatophyte infection that commonly presents as annular, scaly plaques with a well-defined edge and central clearing. These ring-like lesions are characteristic of tinea infections.

 

 

 

Option B. Porokeratosis: This is a disorder of keratinization that presents with annular plaques with a distinct ridge-like border. The characteristic lesion of porokeratosis is an annular plaque with a raised, ridge-like border and central atrophy.

 

 

Option C. Pityriasis rosea: This condition often begins with a single herald patch followed by the development of multiple oval, scaly lesions that may have a ring or annular appearance. The distribution is often in a Christmas-tree pattern on the back.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urticaria is characterized by transient erythematous plaques that do not typically present as annular lesions, unlike conditions such as tinea corporis, porokeratosis, and pityriasis rosea.

questions.text: A male patient complained of bone and joint pain and was prescribed NSAIDs. After a few days, he returned with vesiculo-bullous lesions that subsequently healed, leaving a brownish discoloration on his face (particularly in the upper lip area), as shown in the image. Based on these symptoms, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fixed drug eruption

 

The given clinical situation suggests a diagnosis of a Fixed drug eruption. Fixed drug eruption is one of the most common forms of drug induced exanthems.

 

A fixed drug eruption is a known adverse drug reaction characterized by recurrent skin eruptions at the same location upon re-exposure to a specific drug. The vesiculo-bullous lesions followed by brownish discoloration can be seen in fixed drug eruptions, making it the most likely diagnosis given the patient's history of NSAID use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaria:

 

  • Etiology: Caused by the Plasmodium parasite, which is transmitted to humans via the bites of infected Anopheles mosquitoes.
  • Clinical Features: Fever (often cyclic), chills, sweating, headaches, muscle pains, fatigue, anemia, jaundice due to hemolysis, and enlargement of the spleen.
  • Why it's not the likely diagnosis: Malaria does not typically cause vesico-bullous lesions or discoloration of the face.

 

Option B. Dengue:

 

  • Etiology: Caused by the dengue virus, which is transmitted through the bite of Aedes mosquitoes.
  • Clinical Features: High fever, severe headache, pain behind the eyes, joint and muscle pain, rash, and mild bleeding (e.g., nose or gum bleed, or easy bruising).
  • Why it's not the likely diagnosis: While dengue can cause rashes, it does not usually result in vesico-bullous lesions or leave a persistent brownish discoloration on the skin.

 

Option C. Chikungunya fever:

 

A strong differential diagnosis is post chikungunya pigmentation (PCP) of the face seen on the nose & cheeks (Chik Sign) as shown in the below image.

 

 

Why it's not the likely diagnosis: However, this is not the answer because there is no antecedent history of fever, myalgia, or other symptoms suggestive of chikungunya. PCP often appears as the fever subsides and may persist for about three to six months. PCP mimics melasma & may be misdiagnosed If proper history is not taken.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fixed drug eruption (FDE)

 

FDE is a drug eruption distinguished by its recurrence at the same sites on re‐challenge with the same drug, hence their site on the skin is fixed, it has a short latency and is benign in nature.

 

FDE typically presents 30 min to 8 h after drug exposure.

 

  • Typically, FDE presents as a sharply‐defined, round or oval erythematous and edematous plaque which evolves to become dusky, violaceous and occasionally vesicular or bullous.
  • Classically hyperpigmentation occurs after lesions heal. Most common cause:
    • NSAIDs - On Lips
    • Cotrimoxazole - On Genitals

 

Acute onset pigmentary changes after NSAID use point toward the diagnosis of FDE. NSAID's are one of the most common drugs causing FDE.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 118 page no 118.11, 118.12

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition pages 141-142, 1633

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with multiple anogenital warts, and the biopsy reveals squamous atypia. Among the various human papillomavirus types, which ones are classified as high-risk? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. HPV 18

 

Explanation:

 

  • Squamous carcinoma is the most prevalent type of cancer associated with HPV infection.
  • Among the various human papillomavirus types, HPV-16 and HPV-18 are considered high-risk and are frequently implicated in the development of cervical, vaginal, and vulval cancers.
  • Other high-risk types include HPV-31, HPV-33, and HPV-35.
  • Genital warts, also known as condyloma acuminata or venereal warts, are most commonly caused by human papillomavirus 6 (HPV-6) and human papillomavirus 11 (HPV-11). These types, referred to as low-risk, have a lower potential to lead to malignancy.

 

Genital warts are highly infectious and are commonly acquired through sexual contact, although non-sexual transmission is also possible.

 

 

Imiquimod and podophyllotoxin are first-line medications prescribed for the treatment of genital warts.

 

IMIQUIMOD:

 

  • Imiquimod cream uses:
    • Actinic keratoses
    • Superficial basal cell carcinoma
    • Genital warts (topical immunomodulation)
       
  • Mechanism of action: Activates toll-like receptors 7 and 8, leading to apoptosis in macrophages, monocytes, and dendritic cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A HPV 2:

  • This type is considered low-risk and is commonly associated with common warts that affect the hands and feet, not with anogenital warts or cancer.

 

Option C & D HPV 6 and HPV 11:

  • These are both low-risk types that are associated with about 90% of genital warts but are not typically linked with cancer.
  • They are known to cause benign conditions like respiratory papillomatosis as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HPV 16 & 18 as high-risk types associated with anogenital cancers, and recognize that HPV 2, 6, and 11 are low-risk types not typically associated with cancer.
  • It’s crucial to know the distinction between low-risk and high-risk HPV types due to the differences in prognosis and management.
  • High-risk types warrant more aggressive monitoring and management due to their association with malignancy.

 

 

References:

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 25 Page no 25.43, 25.55

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition 198

Shaws textbook of gynaecology 16th edition 156, 157, 486

Jawetz Melnick & Adelbergs Medical Microbiology 28th edition Page no 650

 

Online resources:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9434721/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK321770/

questions.text: Postherpetic neuralgia (PHN) is characterized by pain persisting beyond how many weeks after the onset of the rash? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. 4 weeks

 

Explanation:


Postherpetic neuralgia (PHN) is the most common and significant neurological complication of herpes zoster (shingles). It is defined as pain that persists after the herpes zoster rash has healed, typically lasting beyond 4 weeks or 1 month from the onset of the rash. This timeframe is used to differentiate PHN from the acute pain associated with the initial herpes zoster infection.

 

Other options:


Option A. 1 week: Pain at this stage is still considered part of the acute phase of herpes zoster, not PHN.


Option B. 2 weeks: Similar to the 1-week mark, pain persisting for 2 weeks is generally considered acute and not classified as PHN.


Option C. 3 weeks: Pain lasting 3 weeks may still be considered part of the acute phase, depending on the individual case, but PHN is typically defined after 4 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:


Postherpetic neuralgia is defined as pain that persists for more than 4 weeks after the onset of a herpes zoster rash

choices.text: Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

questions.text: A young male, aged 24, has presented with asymptomatic scaly skin lesions on his back, symmetrically distributed. The provided images showcase the lesions. Can you identify the pattern of these skin lesions & the specific disease? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

 

Given clinical scenario and images showing Collarette scale (Herald patch) and Christmas tree pattern distributed lesions, points to a diagnosis of Pityriasis rosea.

 

PITYRIASIS ROSEA

 

  • Acute: Self-limiting (6-12 weeks) disease.
  • Etiology: Most common viral trigger is HHV 7.
  • Asymptomatic >> mild pruritus may be present.
  • Features:
    • 1st lesion: Herald patch / mother patch 1-2 weeks later.
    • Secondary lesions: Scaly papules → oval annular plaques → mild pigmentary changes → fades slowly in 6-12 weeks.
  • Distribution of Lesions: Christmas tree pattern (Downwards & outwards from the spine along the lines of Langer).
  • Treatment: Counsel, self-limiting 6-12 weeks.

 

Other Options

 

Option B: Wickham’s striae - Lichen Planus

 

  • Incorrect: Lichen Planus is characterized by pruritic, purple, polygonal papules and plaques. Wickham’s striae are white, lacy lines seen on the surface of lesions, typically not featuring a Christmas tree pattern.

 

 

Option C: Christmas tree pattern - Lichen Planus

 

  • Incorrect: While Lichen Planus can have a wide distribution, it does not typically display a Christmas tree pattern, which is specifically associated with Pityriasis rosea.

 

Option D: Wornoff ring – Seborrheic Dermatitis

 

  • Incorrect: Seborrheic Dermatitis typically presents with oily, scaly patches on the scalp, face, and other sebaceous areas, not as a Christmas tree pattern on the back.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Pityriasis rosea is primarily based on the characteristic appearance and distribution of the rash, with the herald patch and subsequent Christmas tree pattern being hallmark features. Awareness of this pattern and the self-limiting nature of the disease helps in reassuring patients and managing expectations regarding the course of the condition

questions.text: In the case of a patient presenting with multiple nodulocystic lesions on the face, which drug is considered the preferred choice for treatment?(AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isotretinoin

 

This is a case of nodular acne. It comes under grade IV/severe acne.

 

Oral isotretinoin, an oral retinoid is indicated for the treatment of severe acne (nodular, acne conglobata & recalcitrant acne.

 

Recalcitrant acne is poorly responsive acne, with less than 50% improvement after 6 months of therapy with combined oral & topical antibiotics.

 

ACNE VULGARIS:

 

  • Most common form of acne.
  • Most characteristic lesion - Comedones.
  • Most severe form of acne vulgaris - Grade IV / Nodulocystic Acne.
  • Most severe form of acne - Acne conglobata.

 

Comedones (are considered as special lesions) are the specific lesions of acne vulgaris

 

Acne is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. Comedonal lesions are the Earliest lesions of acne. They represent the keratin plugs of the pilosebaceous duct.

 

When the keratin plug is inside the follicle, it is called a closed comedone or whitehead .

 

When the keratin plug is exposed to the environment, it gets oxidised by the air & turns black which is known as open comedone (blackhead)

 

Stages of acne

 

 

According to Global alliance algorithm for acne, Oral isotretinoin is indicated for the treatment of severe acne.

 

Global alliance algorithm for acne treatment

 

Image: global alliance algorithm for improving outcomes in acne

 

Global alliance algorithm for acne treatment:

 

 

 

BPO= Benzoyl peroxide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Steroids particularly corticosteroids, can reduce inflammation and are sometimes used to treat severe inflammatory conditions. However, systemic corticosteroids are generally not a first-line treatment for nodulocystic acne because of their potential side effects, including exacerbating acne upon withdrawal. Intralesional corticosteroids can be used for large, painful nodules but are not the primary treatment for widespread nodulocystic acne.

 

Option C. Erythromycin: It is an antibiotic that can be used to treat acne due to its antibacterial effects against Cutibacterium acnes (formerly Propionibacterium acnes), the bacteria partly responsible for acne. However, it is not as effective as isotretinoin for severe nodulocystic acne and is generally used for less severe forms or when other treatments are contraindicated.

 

Option D. Tetracycline: It is another class of antibiotics used in the treatment of acne. While tetracyclines can be effective for inflammatory acne, they are typically less effective than isotretinoin for severe nodulocystic acne and are not the preferred treatment in such cases.

 

Educational Objective::

 

Isotretinoin is the preferred treatment for severe nodulocystic acne due to its comprehensive action on reducing sebum production, decreasing inflammation, and normalizing keratinization.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 page no 90.7 & 90.37

choices.text: All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotic
Caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space

questions.text: A 55-year-old female came to the hospital with a history of trauma to the ear. On examination, there is swelling, tenderness, and discoloration of the ear. Which of the following is false regarding the given image? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Resolves spontaneously

 

A hematoma of the auricle is depicted in the image given.

 

The scenario described seems to suggest a case of auricular hematoma, which is a collection of blood in the perichondrial space of the ear, usually following trauma. Here is a breakdown of the options provided:

 

This statement is false regarding Perichondral hematoma . If an Perichondral hematoma is left untreated, it usually does not resolve spontaneously. Instead, it often requires intervention to prevent complications such as infection or the development of 'Cauliflower ear'. The standard treatment involves aspiration of the hematoma or surgical intervention to prevent permanent deformity and to reestablish the connection between the cartilage and the overlying perichondrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotic: While not all cases may strictly require prophylactic antibiotics, they are often administered in practice to prevent infection, especially because the ear cartilage is avascular and therefore more susceptible to infection. The effectiveness of prophylactic antibiotics is debated, but it is a common practice, particularly when there's been a break in the skin.

 

Option B. May lead to Pugilistic ear: This is true. A 'Pugilistic ear' is another term for 'Cauliflower ear', which can occur if an auricular hematoma is not adequately treated, leading to fibrosis and cartilage deformity.

 

Option C. Caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space: This is correct. An auricular hematoma occurs when blood accumulates in the space between the cartilage and the perichondrium, which can occur after a blunt trauma to the ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perichondral hematoma (cauliflower ear, wrestler's ear, or pugilistic ear):

 

  • It is a deformity of the ear brought on by repeated trauma.
  • Perichondral space refers to the area of blood between the auricular cartilage and its perichondrium.
  • Due to blunt trauma, it is frequently observed in boxers, wrestlers, and rugby players.
  • It does not resolve spontaneously.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Prophylactic antibiotics should be administered in all cases.
  • Under strict aseptic guidelines, aspiration of the hematoma and application of a pressure dressing to stop re-accumulation.
  • Aspiration might have to be done again. Aspiration that doesn't work should be followed by incision and drainage.

 

Ref - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470424/

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents to the OPD. She had itchy lesions on her arm as shown with a family history of asthma. What could be the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atopic dermatitis

 

  • The image displays scratch marks and excoriations caused by pruritic lesions at a flexural site. The patient has a personal history of chronic and recurrent course, and there is also a family history of atopy, specifically asthma. These findings suggest a diagnosis of atopic dermatitis (AD) or atopic eczema (AE).

 

Atopic dermatitis (AD):

 

  • It is a chronic inflammatory condition that tends to persist or exhibit chronic relapses.
  • In infants, the first site of involvement is often the face.
  • Flexural distribution is observed in both the childhood and adult phases of the condition, while in the infantile phase, extensor distribution is more typical.

 

Atopic eczema can be divided into 3 phases:

 

  1. Infantile
  2. Childhood
  3. Adult

 

 

Atopic eczema infantile variant with face affected:

 

 

  • Atopic dermatitis typically presents with erythematous papules or papulovesicular lesions, often appearing in early childhood.
  • As the condition progresses, the lesions may evolve into excoriated and lichenified areas. Atopic dermatitis is commonly associated with secondary infections and skin dryness.
  • In the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis, the UK refinement of the Hanifin & Rajka criteria is employed.

 

UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (Eczema).

 

  • An itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child)
  • Plus, three or more of the following
    1. Onset below age 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
    2. History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
    3. History of a generally dry skin
    4. Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first degree relative in children under 4 years)
    5. Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/ forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

 

Clinical features of AD include:

 

  • Dennie-morgan fold under lower eyelid
  • Allergic shiners – periorbital pigmentation
  • Allergic salute – horizontal groove on dorsum of nasal bridge

 

 

Fig: Dennie-morgan fold

 

Complications of AD:

 

  • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism to cause secondary infections in the lesions of atopic dermatitis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Seborrheic dermatitis:

 

  • This is a chronic condition that primarily affects sebum-rich areas of the body such as the scalp, face, and central chest.
  • It's characterized by yellowish, greasy scales and underlying erythema as shown in the image below.

 

 

 

  • While it can be itchy, its distribution and features are different from the description given.
  • There is no direct association between seborrheic dermatitis and a family history of asthma.

 

Option C. Allergic contact dermatitis:

  • This results from direct skin contact with allergens. It's an immunological response to a substance the individual has become sensitized to.
  • The lesions would be more correlated with contact to specific allergens, and it's not typically chronic or recurrent unless there is repeated exposure to the same allergen.
  • The distribution would be more in line with areas that contacted the allergen, rather than the typical flexural pattern described.

 

Option D. Erysipelas:

  • Erysipelas is an acute bacterial skin infection, typically caused by Group A Streptococcus.
  • It presents as a well-demarcated, raised, erythematous, and tender skin lesion, often accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever.
  • This condition is acute, not chronic or recurrent as described in the scenario.
  • There's no association with a family history of asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atopic dermatitis is a chronic, pruritic inflammatory skin disease commonly associated with flexural distribution of eczematous lesions and a family history of atopic conditions, such as asthma.

 

References:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 2 Chapter 41 page no 41.1, 41.2, 41.13-19

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 3 Chapter 149 page no 149.21

Online resources:

https://www.jaad.org/article/S0190-9622(13)01095-5/fulltext

Question Level – Intermediate

Question Id-7456 Unique Key-Q3994123

questions.text:
Among the listed causes of alopecia, which one(s) result in non-scarring alopecia? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Alopecia areata
  2. Telogen effluvium
  3. Androgenic alopecia
  4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, and 3

 

 

Non cicatricial alopecia classification:

 

 

Option 1 - Alopecia areata:

 

  • It is a persistent autoimmune condition characterized by non-scarring hair loss patches.
  • This inflammatory disease involves T cells and primarily affects individuals with genetic susceptibility, being associated with HLA DR4, DR5, DQ3.
  • The condition is identifiable by "exclamation mark hairs" – short, fragile hairs that taper toward the base, as illustrated in the image below.

 

 

  • Alopecia totalis refers to the complete loss of scalp hair.
  • Alopecia universalis involves the loss of all body hair.
  • In instances of limited alopecia areata, approximately 80% of patients experience spontaneous remission.
  • Alopecia areata predominantly affects pigmented hair.
  • In older individuals, gray hair may consist of both white and colored hair. If the disease progresses rapidly, only the colored hair will be affected and lost, leaving the white hair unaffected in the patches of hair loss.
  • This sudden change in hair color is known as "Turning white overnight".

 

The following image depicts sparing of white hair within patches of hair loss.

 

 

Fig: Alopecia areata " Turning white overnight"

 

Option 2 - Telogen effluvium:

 

  • It is an acute onset of scalp hair loss that starts one to two months after a trigger, such as a high fever, infections (Cholera, Typhoid, Covid), trauma from surgery or other trauma, starvation, MI, Pregnancy, or hemorrhage.
  • It refers to an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to premature termination of anagen proliferative phase of the hair cycle following a period of stress.
  • Telogen hair shedding that lasts longer than six months is known as chronic diffuse telogen hair loss.
  • Thyroid conditions (both hyper- and hypothyroidism), severe iron deficiency Anemia, acrodermatitis enteropathica, and malnutrition are the main causes of chronic diffuse telogen hair loss.

 

Option 3 - Androgenetic Alopecia

 

  • The disorder known as androgenetic alopecia is characterized by the miniaturization & reduction of hair follicle production.
  • Male pattern hair loss and female pattern hair loss are the two types.
  • Recession of the frontal hairline and vertex thinning are seen in male pattern hair loss.
  • Females may experience male pattern hair loss, and the opposite is also true.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option 4 - Frontal fibrosing alopecia

 

  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia is a scalp condition that affects post-menopausal women in particular and frequently involves the eyebrows.
  • It is a type of primary cicatricial (scarring) alopecia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-scarring alopecia’s do not destroy the hair follicle and allow for the possibility of hair regrowth.
  • Scarring alopecia’s involve destruction and replacement of the hair follicle with scar tissue, leading to permanent hair loss.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 89 page no 89.25, 28, 33

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page 1509

Online resource: https://www.bmj.com/content/347/bmj.f6112

questions.text: Which component of cement causes allergic contact dermatitis among construction workers in India? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chromate

 

  • It is a component of chromium, is commonly used in the manufacturing of cement and is a well-known cause of allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) among construction workers due to their frequent and prolonged exposure to wet cement.
  • Chromate can cause ACD through a type IV delayed hypersensitivity reaction.
  • When cement containing chromate comes into contact with the skin, particularly in the presence of moisture, the chromate can leach out and result in sensitization and subsequent dermatitis.
  • Allergic contact dermatitis is an inflammatory response to an allergen that only manifests as an eruption in people who have already been sensitized to the allergen.
  • The diagnosis of ACD is made by Patch test with the culprit substances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cobalt: Cobalt is less commonly a cause of ACD in construction workers compared to chromate. Cobalt may be present in tools or dyes, but not typically in cement.

 

Option B. Nickel: Nickel is a well-known cause of ACD, often associated with exposure to nickel-containing jewellery or clothing items, not with cement.

 

Option C. Iron: Iron, while common in construction materials, is not a frequent cause of ACD. It is not known to be an allergen that would typically induce contact dermatitis.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among construction workers in India, allergic contact dermatitis is most commonly caused by chromate in cement, due to a type IV hypersensitivity reaction when chromate comes into contact with the skin.

 

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 128 page no 128.2-14

Online source: https://europepmc.org/article/pmc/2965911

choices.text: Stop MDT and start oral steroids
Continue MDT and add oral steroids

questions.text: In a pregnant woman at 12 weeks of gestation, who is currently undergoing multidrug therapy (MDT) for leprosy, she now presents with type 2 lepra reaction. What is the preferred treatment for this patient?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Continue MDT and add oral steroids

 

To manage a pregnant woman experiencing a type 2 lepra reaction, it is essential to continue the multidrug therapy (MDT) while adding oral steroids as an additional treatment.

 

  • In the management of leprosy, it is crucial to continue multidrug therapy (MDT) to effectively treat the underlying infection caused by Mycobacterium leprae.
  • A Type 2 lepra reaction, also known as erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL), is a complex immunological reaction that occurs in lepromatous and borderline lepromatous leprosy, which can present with painful nodules, fever, malaise, and other systemic symptoms.
  • Oral steroids, such as prednisone, are the treatment of choice for controlling acute inflammatory complications associated with Type 2 lepra reaction. They help reduce inflammation and immune response.
  • It is important to manage the reaction without discontinuing the MDT to prevent the development of drug resistance and further progression of the disease.

 

Erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL)

 

  • It is a type 3 hypersensitive immune complex-mediated reaction that affects the skin, nerves, and other organs.
  • It is typically recurrent and commonly observed in individuals with multibacillary leprosy. ENL may occur before treatment, during treatment or after completion of treatment.
  • It is characterized by painful, erythematous nodules appearing on the extensor surfaces of the limbs and face.

 

In a type 2 lepra reaction, systemic symptoms such as iritis, orchitis, and the appearance of fresh skin lesions can be observed.

 

Treatment includes:

 

  • High doses of glucocorticoids are frequently administered to all patients which assist in reducing the acute signs and symptoms of inflammation.
  • In patients with lepra reactions, MDT is never discontinued.
  • Only severe cases of type-2 lepra reaction or erythema nodosum Leprosum are treated with thalidomide. Thalidomide is gold standard for type II Lepra reaction, but it is NOT the Drug of Choice due to its cost factor & also its Adverse drug reactions profile.

 

Type I & II lepra reactions (ENL= Erythema Nodosum Leprosum):

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop MDT and start oral steroids: Stopping MDT is not advisable because it can lead to the proliferation of Mycobacterium leprae and risk the development of drug resistance.

 

Option B. Antibiotics: While antibiotics are a part of MDT to treat the bacterial infection, they alone are not sufficient to address the acute inflammatory symptoms of a Type 2 lepra reaction.

 

Option C. Thalidomide:

 

  • Thalidomide is an effective treatment for Type 2 lepra reactions due to its potent anti-inflammatory properties.
  • However, it is absolutely contraindicated in pregnant women due to its teratogenic effects, which can cause severe birth defects as seen in the below image.

 

 

Phocomelia

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a pregnant woman with leprosy who presents with a Type 2 lepra reaction, the preferred treatment is to continue multidrug therapy and add oral steroids to manage the acute inflammatory symptoms.
  • Thalidomide is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its teratogenicity.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page no 28.16

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 21st edition page no 1387, 1390

choices.text: Scleredema is commonly associated with diabetes mellitus and affects the neck and upper back.
Scleredema presents with thickened, non-pitting induration of the skin without involvement of the hands and feet.
Scleredema is associated with sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s phenomenon.
Scleredema results in an expanded dermis due to increased mucin deposition and thick collagen fibers.

questions.text: Which statement is false regarding scleredema?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Scleredema is associated with sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s phenomenon.

 

Explanation:

 

Scleredema and scleroderma are distinct conditions, and scleredema is not associated with features like sclerodactyly, Raynaud’s phenomenon, nail fold capillary changes, or serum autoantibodies, which are characteristic of scleroderma. Scleredema primarily affects the skin on the upper back and neck, sparing the hands and feet. It involves increased mucin deposition and thickened collagen fibers without fibroblast proliferation. The most common form of scleredema is associated with diabetes mellitus, particularly in men, due to abnormal collagen synthesis and resistance to degradation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scleredema is commonly associated with diabetes mellitus and affects the neck and upper back.
This statement is true. Scleredema is frequently associated with diabetes, particularly in men, and primarily involves the neck and upper back regions, leading to skin tightening and thickening.

 

Option B. Scleredema presents with thickened, non-pitting induration of the skin without involvement of the hands and feet.
This is correct. Scleredema characteristically spares the hands and feet, and it presents with non-pitting induration mainly on the back and neck.

 

Option D. Scleredema results in an expanded dermis due to increased mucin deposition and thick collagen fibers.
This is also true. Scleredema is marked by thickening of the dermis caused by mucin deposition and coarse collagen fibers, which distinguish it from other skin conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scleredema is a condition characterized by thickened, taut skin predominantly affecting the upper back and neck, often associated with diabetes. It is distinct from scleroderma, as it lacks features such as sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s phenomenon. Understanding the differences between these

questions.text: A child with a history of night-blindness presented to you with the following findings. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Phrynoderma

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of a child with night blindness and multiple hyperkeratotic papules on the elbows, as depicted in the image, raises suspicion of a diagnosis called phrynoderma or toad-skin. This condition is often linked to a deficiency of vitamin A (VAD).
  • It is characterized by the development of keratotic follicular papules, initially appearing on the anterolateral thighs and posterolateral upper arms, and subsequently spreading to the extensor surfaces of the extremities, shoulders, abdomen, back, buttocks, face, and posterior neck.
  • While originally reported in association with vitamin A deficiency, phrynoderma is a non-specific finding that can also be observed in deficiencies of B-complex vitamins, vitamin C, vitamin E, essential fatty acids (EFA deficiency), protein-energy malnutrition (PEM), and general states of malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Keratosis pilaris:

  • Description: Keratosis pilaris is a common, benign skin condition that manifests as tiny, rough-feeling bumps on the skin, often likened to "chicken skin." It frequently occurs on the upper arms, thighs, or cheeks.
  • It usually presents during puberty. Perifollicular erythema in addition to follicular plugging
  • Favors the upper outer arms and the thighs, but lacks discrete clusters. Treatment is purely reserved for cosmetic purposes.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis:  While keratosis pilaris can appear on the upper arms close to the elbows, it's not specifically associated with night-blindness or vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option C. Darier disease:

  • Description: Darier disease is a rare, genetic skin disorder characterized by small, hard bumps on the skin, especially on the chest, back, and forehead. These may be yellowish in color and often have a foul odor.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis While Darier disease causes papules, it is not associated with night-blindness. Other features of Darier disease are also not mentioned in the question.

 

Option D. Follicular eczema:

  • Description: This is a variant of eczema (atopic dermatitis) that specifically affects the hair follicles, leading to itchy, inflamed skin.
  • Reasons it might not fit: Though follicular eczema can cause papules, the association with night-blindness is not seen. Eczema would typically be associated with itching and possibly a history of allergies or atopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical students preparing for residency, it is crucial to associate the findings of follicular hyperkeratotic papules, especially when coupled with systemic symptoms such as night-blindness, with phrynoderma, a condition related to vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Reference:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page no 63.8

questions.text: A 65-year-old guy arrives with tense, itchy bullae over his limbs. The roof of the bullae collapsed after a few days. What is the most likely diagnosis shown in the clinical image below? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bullous pemphigoid

 

The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of bullous pemphigoid.

 

  • Elderly aged people are usually affected.
  • It presents as tense itchy bulla, which do not rupture easily, which can have an erythematous base (urticarial wheals) & the roof of the bullae collapses after a few days forming settled bulla, autoantibodies (IgG) against BP180 (BPAG2) and BP 230 (BPAG1) antigens on hemidesmosomes are seen in these patients.
  • It is a subepidermal blistering disorder, so acantholysis will not be seen.
  • Histopathology: subepidermal bullae with eosinophils
  • DIF: deposition of IgG antibodies at the dermo-epidermal junction in a linear pattern.
  • It is mainly treated with Topical corticosteroids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pemphigus vulgaris: This is another autoimmune blistering disorder. However, the blisters in pemphigus vulgaris are flaccid and easily ruptured as shown in the image below, as opposed to the tense bullae seen in bullous pemphigoid. Additionally, the oral mucosa is frequently involved in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

 

Option C. Dermatitis herpetiformis: This condition is associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease) and presents with itchy papules, vesicles, and bullae. However, the distribution is typically on extensor surfaces like elbows and knees as shown in the image below, and the appearance differs from what is shown in the image in the MCQ.

 

 

Option D. Linear IgA dermatosis: This is a rare autoimmune blistering disorder. The blisters are typically in a "string of pearls" or annular arrangement as shown in the image below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Bullous Pemphigoid is a subepidermal blistering disorder predominantly affecting the elderly, characterized by tense itchy bullae, autoantibodies against BP180 and BP230, and eosinophilic involvement."

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50, Page no. 50.4-50.37.

questions.text: After administering the patch test to a 10-year-old boy with a history of allergic contact dermatitis, when should you schedule his return for patch removal? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 48 hours

 

The Gold standard Diagnostic test for Airborne contact dermatitis (ABCD) & Allergic Contact Dermatitis (ACD) is a patch test. 

 

Patch testing:

 

  • It is a method used to determine if a specific substance causes allergic inflammation of a patient's skin.
  • It is typically indicated for patients with suspected allergic contact dermatitis.
  • The test involves the application of various substances in small chambers or patches to the skin, usually on the back.
  • After the application of a patch test, the patches are generally removed at 48 hours (2 days), and an initial reading is taken.
  • This timeframe allows for the elicitation of a Type IV or delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction, which is the basis of allergic contact dermatitis.
  • However, readings at 48 hours may not be sufficient to detect all reactions, and thus an additional reading at 96 hours is often recommended.
  • The additional reading helps to identify late reactions, which could otherwise be missed if only the 48-hour reading is considered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 24 hours

 

  • This timeframe is too short for most delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions to occur.
  • Removing the patches at 24 hours would likely result in missing many positive reactions.

 

Option B. 72 hours

 

  • It is not typically when the patches are first removed.
  • The patches are usually removed at 48 hours, and the skin is then inspected for any reactions.

 

Option D. 96 hours

 

  • This is a common time for a follow-up reading and not the initial removal of the patches.
  • Some protocols suggest readings at this time to ensure that late-appearing reactions are not missed.

 

The image below shows a patch test:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref- Rooks textbook of dermatology - 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4 page no 4.23

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page no 406

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3900336/

questions.text: A patient presents with following lesions on the genitals. Scrapings from the lesion would show? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both A & B

 

Tzanck cells & MNGCs can be seen in Herpes lesions.

 

The provided image displays clusters of vesicles on an erythematous base, indicative of a possible diagnosis of genital herpes caused by Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.

 

Tzanck smear:

 

  • To perform a Tzanck smear, scrapings are obtained from the lesions, preferably from the base of the vesicles.
  • Smears are then prepared and stained with a 1% aqueous solution of O-toluidine blue for 15 seconds, which allows the visualization of acantholytic and multinucleated giant cells.
  • In Herpes infections, Tzanck smear examination may reveal the presence of Tzanck cells and multinucleated giant cells.

 

Below image depicts Acantholytic cells

 

 

Below image depicts multinucleated giant cells

 

 

  • Tzanck or Acantholytic cells are formed as a result of acantholysis, which is the breakdown of intercellular connections, like desmosomes.
  • This process leads to a reduction in cohesiveness among keratinocytes.

 

Acantholysis is classified as:

 

 

Other Option:

 

Option D. Henderson Patterson bodies:

 

  • These are intracytoplasmic inclusions seen in cells infected with molluscum contagiosum, a skin infection caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus.
  • This is not consistent with the lesion shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Herpes simplex virus infections, scrapings from lesions may show both Acantholytic / Tzanck cells and Multinucleate giant cells (MNGCs).

 

Ref - Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 474-476

questions.text: Which causative agent is responsible for the 4-year-old boy's condition, characterized by painful mouth sores, a rash on the hands, and fever as shown below? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coxsackievirus

 

The above scenario is suggestive of hand-foot-and-mouth disease. It is most commonly caused by coxsackievirus A16 (CV-A16).CV‐A6 and EV71 are also other important causative organisms.

 

  • Age group commonly affected: Children.
  • Spread: Droplets / fecal contamination.
  • Incubation period: 7 days.
  • Clinical features: In children, the onset is with a low‐grade fever, sore throat and malaise but in adults, a painful stomatitis is an early feature. 
    • Blisters in the mouth soon break down to superficial ulcers.
    • Children are more likely than adults to develop flaccid greyish 2–5 mm oval vesicles on the palms and slightly less frequently on the soles.
  • They fade after 2–3 days. Infection can be subclinical.
  • Only symptomatic treatment is given.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pox virus:

 

  • Poxviruses cause diseases such as smallpox and molluscum contagiosum, which have very different clinical presentations from HFMD.
  • Smallpox, which has been eradicated, presented with a characteristic vesicular and pustular rash and high mortality.
  • Molluscum contagiosum is characterized by firm, painless, umbilicated papules, not the presentation seen in the images provided.

 

Option C. HHV-7 (Human Herpesvirus-7):

 

  • HHV-7 is associated with roseola, a viral infection characterized by a high fever and a rash.
  • HHV 7 is also associated with Pityriasis rosea.
  • However, it does not typically cause painful mouth sores or a rash on the hands.

 

Option D. Parvovirus: Parvovirus B19 can cause a condition called fifth disease, which may result in a rash on the face classically described as slapped cheek appearance as shown in the below image

 

 

but parvo virus not known for causing painful mouth sores or a rash on the hands. Additionally, fifth disease is more common in children between 5 and 15 years old, so it is less likely in a 4-year-old.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of fever, painful oral sores, and a vesicular rash on the hands and feet in a young child is characteristic of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease, which is most commonly caused by Coxsackievirus.

 

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition, Chapter 25 Page no 25.81, chapter 117, Page no 117.6

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 1591

questions.text: A male baby, born to a non-consanguineous couple, presents with blisters on areas of friction. Their previous baby also experienced similar issues and unfortunately passed away at the age of 2 weeks. What is the probable diagnosis?(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epidermolysis bullosa

 

  • The male baby's current condition, characterized by blisters appearing in areas of friction, along with a similar history in a sibling, strongly suggests a diagnosis of a genetic condition called as epidermolysis bullosa congenita.
  • Epidermolysis bullosa is a mechano-bullous disease where blisters develop in response to mechanical trauma, often occurring in regions prone to friction such as the hands, feet, elbows, and knees.

 

 

Various types of Epidermolysis bullosa (EB) & Defects associated with them:

 

 

Other options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The likely diagnosis in a neonate presenting with blistering at areas of friction, especially with a similar family history and early demise in a sibling, is Epidermolysis bullosa, a genetic condition causing extremely fragile skin leading to blister formation with minimal trauma.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 71 Page no 71.4-71.16

choices.text: Loose anagen hair

questions.text: A 27-year-old married woman presents with patchy hair loss in the right temporal and occipital areas. Upon examination, she exhibits non-scarring alopecia with several short, broken hairs. Scalp scrapings reveal mild inflammation, peri-follicular hemorrhage, and a slight lymphocytic infiltration. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. TRICHOTILLOMANIA

 

Explanation:


The clinical presentation of patchy hair loss with non-scarring alopecia and the presence of short, broken hairs in the temporal and occipital regions strongly suggests trichotillomania. This condition involves compulsive hair-pulling behavior, leading to the distinct findings of broken hairs and mild perifollicular inflammation, as observed on scalp examination. The peri-follicular hemorrhage and mild lymphocytic infiltration seen in the scrapings further support this diagnosis.

 

Other options:


Option A. Alopecia areata: Typically presents with smooth, round patches of hair loss without broken hairs or significant inflammation.


Option B. Androgenic alopecia: Characterized by diffuse hair thinning rather than patchy hair loss, and it generally does not involve broken hairs or inflammation.


Option C. Loose anagen hair: This condition involves easily extractable hairs in the anagen phase but does not present with patchy hair loss and broken hairs like trichotillomania.

 

Educational Objective:


Trichotillomania is identified by patchy hair loss with short, broken hairs, often due to compulsive hair-pulling behavior.

questions.text: Identify the drug used to treat the condition shown below: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Anti-tubercular therapy

 

  • The image showing a plaque with one margin extending & other margin healing with scarring (Asymmetrical lesion), this favors to the diagnosis of lupus vulgaris, which is treated using anti-tubercular drugs.
  • It is the most common cutaneous tuberculosis in adults in India.
  • It occurs in previously sensitized hosts with good immunity.
  • Granulomas with little to no caseation can be seen on histology.

 

Lupus Vulgaris

 

  • Lupus vulgaris is a chronic form of skin TB seen in patients with moderate immunity to TB bacilli
  • It is seen more common in females.

 

Pathogenesis:

 

  • It occurs due to hematogenous, lymphatic, or contiguous spread from elsewhere in the body, or from exogenous inoculation. It occurs in previously sensitized hosts with good immunity, hence Paucibacillary.

 

Clinical features

 

  • It presents as single or few lesions which are well demarcated, annular plaques which extend centrifugally. Periphery show erythematous deep-seated nodules which on diascopy may stand out as apple jelly nodules as seen in the image below.

 

 

  •  They are most commonly seen in buttocks, upper extremities, and face. Center is depigmented with paper-thin scar with nodules.
  • Papules may recur on the scarred areas, which enlarge and coalesce. This leads to the formation of large, firm, elevated plaques.

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Histologic examination & a positive culture for M. tuberculosis/ bovis confirm the diagnosis
  • Most prominent histopathologic feature: Typical granulomas with scanty or absent caseation.

 

Complication

 

  • Secondary scarring & squamous cell carcinomas may develop rarely.

 

Treatment:

Anti-tubercular drugs.

 

CLASSIFICATION OF CUTANEOUS TUBERCULOSIS IS BASED ON THE MODE OF ACQUISITION:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical steroids therapy:

  • This is not the appropriate treatment for lupus vulgaris.
  • Topical steroids are used for inflammatory conditions, and while they may reduce inflammation and symptoms temporarily, they do not address the underlying mycobacterial infection that causes lupus vulgaris.

 

Option B. Anti-leprosy treatment:

  • Although leprosy is also caused by a mycobacterium (Mycobacterium leprae) and anti-leprosy drugs are used to treat it, the clinical features described do not match leprosy.
  • Moreover, the treatment regimens for leprosy and tuberculosis are different.

 

Option C. Anti-fungal therapy:

  • Fungal infections can present with skin lesions, but the description of the lesion as characteristic of lupus vulgaris does not fit a fungal infection.
  • Anti-fungal therapy would not be effective against mycobacterial infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis characterized by irregular plaques that show progression at one margin and healing with scarring at another, and to understand that the appropriate treatment is a multi-drug anti-tubercular therapy regimen.

 

References:

 

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 27.21-27.23, 32.35-32.36, 33.44-33.45

choices.text: Acanthosis nigricans – Insulin resistance
Stria albicans – Cushing syndrome
Xeroderma pigmentosum – Freckles
Café au lait spots – McCune Albright syndrome

questions.text: An overweight 13-year-old girl has the following blackish discoloration on her neck, as shown in the image below. What is this condition and its association? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acanthosis nigricans – Insulin resistance

 

Option A.

 

Acanthosis Nigricans:

 

  • This condition is characterized by velvety, hyperpigmented plaques typically found in the intertriginous areas such as the neck, axilla, and groin.
  • The lesion’s appearance in the image is consistent with Acanthosis Nigricans.
  • It is commonly associated with insulin resistance and can be a marker for type 2 diabetes mellitus, especially in the context of overweight or obesity, as seen in the patient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Striae Albicans:

 

  • This refers to the white or silver stretch marks that occur when the skin has been stretched rapidly as in the case of rapid weight gain or with conditions like Cushing syndrome.

 

 

  • However, the image does not show stretch marks but rather a hyperpigmented, thickened area of skin.

 

Option C. Xeroderma Pigmentosum:

 

  • This is a rare genetic disorder characterized by extreme sensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) rays from sunlight, leading to an increased risk of skin cancer.

 

 

  • The lesions associated with this condition are more freckle-like and do not resemble the thick, velvety texture seen in the image.

 

Option D. Café au lait spots:

 

  • These are light brown to dark brown spots commonly associated with neurofibromatosis or McCune-Albright syndrome.

 

 

  • Unlike Acanthosis Nigricans, café au lait spots are smooth in texture and uniform in pigmentation, not velvety or thickened.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize Acanthosis Nigricans by its velvety, hyperpigmented plaques on the neck and its association with insulin resistance in the context of obesity.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 87.2

questions.text: Identify the instrument:  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Maddox rod

 

The above instrument is a Maddox rod.

 

A Maddox rod is a specially constructed device, consisting of a series of parallel cylinders, that converts a point source of light into a line image. It can be used to test for horizontal and vertical deviations, and when used in conjunction with another Maddox rod, for cyclo deviations.

 

Maddox Rod Test

 

Patient is asked to fix on a point light in the centre of Maddox tangent scale at a distance of 6 metres. A Maddox rod (which consists of many glass rods of red colour set together in a metallic disc) is placed in front of one eye with axis of the rod parallel to the axis of deviation.

 

 

 

Due to dissimilar images of the two eyes, fusion is broken and heterophoria becomes manifest. The number on the Maddox tangent scale where the red line falls will be the amount of heterophoria in degrees.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maddox wing: An instrument used to measure the horizontal and vertical deviations at near using a different mechanism involving a scale and moving wings.

 

Option B. Maddox glass: This term is not commonly used; it might refer to the Maddox rod or Maddox wing.

 

Option D. Phoropter: An instrument used in refraction testing to determine eyeglass prescriptions, consisting of multiple lenses that can be rotated into place to assess visual acuity and lens power.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Maddox rod is an instrument consisting of parallel cylindrical lenses used to convert a point light source into a line image, aiding in the diagnosis of horizontal, vertical, and cyclo deviations in ocular alignment.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with a satellite skin lesion. On examination, the patient has one hypopigmented lesion and one thickened nerve. The images of two blister packs are provided. Based on the WHO / NLEP Guidelines, which treatment is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer:

The correct answer is B. Packet 2 for 12 months.

Latest Guidelines for Leprosy: NLEP = WHO (from April 1, 2025)

As of April 1, 2025, India's NLEP has aligned completely with WHO guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of leprosy. This means that the same criteria and drug regimens are now followed globally and in India.

 

*If a case has any one of the three features suggestive of MB, he/she is classified as MB.

 

Treatment Regimen: WHO & NLEP (Post April 1st 2025)

 

Other Options:

Option A: Packet 1 for 12 months: 

This packet was used for the treatment of paucibacillary leprosy according to old guidelines of NLEP, which is not suitable for a patient with multibacillary leprosy.

Option C: Packet 1 for 6 months: 

This packet was used for the treatment of paucibacillary leprosy according to old guidelines of NLEP, which is not suitable for a patient with multibacillary leprosy.

Option D Packet 2 for 6 months: 

Although Packet 2 contains the correct medications, the treatment duration of 6 months is insufficient for multibacillary leprosy according to WHO guidelines, which recommends 12 months.

 

OLD NLEP GUIDELINES to diagnose Leprosy 

OLD NLEP GUIDELINES to treat Leprosy 

OLD PB MDT with 2 drugs followed by NLEP:

 

Educational objective:

  • As of April 1, 2025, NLEP follows WHO guidelines for both diagnosis and treatment.
  • Classification is based on skin lesions, nerve involvement, and skin smear.
  • For a patient with multibacillary leprosy, characterized by one or more thickened nerves and multiple skin lesions, the appropriate treatment is with a regimen containing rifampicin, clofazimine, and dapsone (Packet 2) for a duration of 12 months.

 

References:

Jopling’s handbook of leprosy, 6th edition, page no 10

Andrew’s diseases of the skin: clinical dermatology 13th edition page no 338, 339, 345

questions.text: An infant is brought to OPD with hepatosplenomegaly and thrombocytopenia. Neuroimaging with CT reveals periventricular calcifications. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Congenital cytomegalovirus infection

 

Congenital CMV is reported to be the commonest congenital infection. The overall transmission rate with primary infection is 30% and 10% of all babies infected are symptomatic. Congenital infection can affect all organ systems. Periventricular calcification is characteristic. The diagnosis of congenital CMV is confirmed by a positive IgM in the first two weeks of life.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital rubella syndrome: Rubella causes most severe form of intra uterine infection. If infection sets within 11 weeks POG – 90% defects, if 11-12 weeks – 33% defects chances. More the weeks pass, less is the frequency of having CRS infections. Presentation is similar like measles rash but rash appears on day 1 & lasts for 3 days (3 days measles). Triad – congenital heart disease (MC – PDA; Least Common – ASD), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL).

 

Option B. Congenital herpes simplex virus infection: The transmission of HSV to babies usually occurs during delivery in mothers who develop primary genital herpes at that time. Infected babies may be asymptomatic or have fulminant disease. Presents with vesicular eruption on to skin, eyes and mouth. CNS disease that presents as meningitis with seizures and altered sensorium. Diagnosis is by Tzanck smear of the skin lesions, culture or PCR of lesions or cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Option C. Congenital toxoplasmosis: Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs due to maternal primary infection, which is generally subclinical may lead to fetal infection and disease. The transmissibility increases but the risk of fetal disease decreases with advancing pregnancy. It presents with a triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Periventricular calcifications on neuroimaging, along with hepatosplenomegaly and thrombocytopenia, are characteristic of congenital cytomegalovirus infection.

questions.text: Cannabinoids are not approved for treatment of (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rett syndrome

 

  • Cannabinoids, including cannabidiol (CBD), are not currently approved for the treatment of Rett syndrome. 
  • Rett syndrome is a rare genetic neurological disorder, and while there is ongoing research into potential treatments, cannabinoids are not among the approved therapies for this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dravet Syndrome: Cannabidiol (CBD) is approved for the treatment of Dravet Syndrome, a severe form of epilepsy. It is used to reduce the frequency of seizures in patients with this condition.

 

Option B. Tuberous sclerosis: Cannabidiol (CBD) is also approved for the treatment of seizures associated with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC). It has been shown to reduce seizure frequency in patients with TSC.

 

Option D. Lennox Gastaut syndrome: Cannabidiol (CBD) is approved for the treatment of Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome, another severe form of epilepsy. It is used to help reduce the frequency of seizures in patients with this syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, cannabinoids, specifically cannabidiol (CBD), are not approved for the treatment of Rett syndrome, whereas they are approved for use in Dravet Syndrome, Tuberous Sclerosis, and Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome.

questions.text: A tuberculosis patient receiving anti-tubercular treatment complains of tingling and paresthesia in the lower limbs. He is not diabetic and drinks alcohol on occasion. Which of the following vitamins should be given to this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6

 

The patient's symptoms of tingling and paresthesia in the lower limbs, in the context of receiving anti-tubercular treatment, are suggestive of peripheral neuropathy. One of the mainstays of tuberculosis (TB) treatment includes the drug isoniazid, which is known to cause vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency. Supplementing with vitamin B6 can prevent or alleviate these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B12: While vitamin B12 deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy, it is not typically associated with anti-tubercular therapy. Vitamin B12 deficiency is more commonly linked to conditions like pernicious anemia or dietary deficiencies.

 

Option C. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin): Deficiency of vitamin B2 can lead to various symptoms, including skin disorders and anemia, but it is not specifically linked to the type of neuropathy seen in patients taking isoniazid for TB.

 

Option D. Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Deficiency of vitamin B3 leads to pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, and is not associated with the peripheral neuropathy observed in patients on isoniazid therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients receiving isoniazid as part of anti-tubercular therapy should be supplemented with vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) to prevent or treat peripheral neuropathy, a common side effect of this medication.

choices.text: Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to base hospital
Perform more small incision cataract surgery
To do surgery in rural area with make shift hospital/Ots
To perform surgeries in fixed facility surgery by shifting patients from rural area.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of progressive vision loss is scheduled for cataract surgery under the National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment. Which of the following is NOT an accurate guideline or inclusion criterion for cataract surgery within this national program? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) To do surgery in rural area with make shift hospital/Ots

 

Explanation:

 

To do surgery in rural area with makeshift hospital/Ots is not advisable, suggests conducting surgeries in temporary setups or less equipped facilities, typically in rural areas. This is considered unsafe and against the guidelines because such environments cannot guarantee the sterility and safety standards required for surgical procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to base hospital: This refers to the standard protocol where patients identified as needing cataract surgery are instructed to come to a base or main hospital that is equipped for such procedures. This ensures that surgeries are performed in a controlled, sterile environment with appropriate medical facilities and staff.

 

Option B. Perform more small incision cataract surgery (SICS): This statement encourages the adoption of small incision cataract surgery, which is a modern technique that allows for quicker recovery times and potentially fewer complications than traditional methods. It is particularly advantageous in resource-limited settings because it does not require expensive machinery like phacoemulsification units.

 

Option D. To perform surgeries in fixed facility surgery by shifting patients from rural area: This approach involves transporting patients from rural and remote areas to fixed, well-equipped surgical facilities, typically located in urban or suburban centers. This ensures all patients receive high-quality care in facilities that meet national and international health and safety standards.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The primary aim of these guidelines is to ensure that all surgeries, particularly sensitive ones like cataract surgery, are performed in environments that uphold the highest standards of medical care and patient safety. The emphasis is on using modern surgical techniques and ensuring that all procedures are carried out in well-equipped, permanent medical facilities to minimize risks and enhance recovery outcomes. The standard guideline includes:

 

  1. Village Register (Linelisting of cases)
  2. Screening camps
  3. Transport of cases to Base hospital
  4. Free surgery – fixed facility surgery approach (Reach in approach at base Hospitals preferred over Reach out approach as camp mode)
  5. Follow up of cases (for this camp mode is preferred)

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)
Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient was brought to the ER after RTA, her RR is 22/min, BP is 90/60mmHg. On examination, hyper-resonance is heard over the right side of the chest. The chest X-ray performed is given below. What would be the appropriate management in this case? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

 

The given scenario of tachypnea, hypotension, hyper-resonance and x ray showing absent right broncho-vascular markings is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

 

This option correctly addresses the likely diagnosis of a pneumothorax. The initial needle insertion can decompress the tension pneumothorax, and subsequent placement of an intercostal drain allows for continuous drainage of pleural air or fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS: This option suggests inserting a needle into the 5th ICS to relieve tension pneumothorax, which can occur due to trauma. While this can be a life-saving procedure, the presence of hyper-resonance on examination suggests a pneumothorax, but it does not address the drainage of pleural fluid, which is the primary concern in this case.

 

Option C. Aspiration of the pleural fluid: Aspiration of pleural fluid may be indicated in cases of pleural effusion, but it does not address the likely pneumothorax seen in this patient's presentation.

 

Option D. No intervention needed: With the patient's clinical presentation, including respiratory distress, low blood pressure, and hyper-resonance, intervention is indeed needed. Failure to intervene could lead to worsening respiratory compromise and potentially life-threatening consequences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tension pneumothorax usually occurs due to trauma, such as a rib fracture, a puncture wound, or chest surgery, but it can also develop spontaneously in patients with underlying lung diseases, such as emphysema or cystic fibrosis.
  • Immediate treatment of tension pneumothorax is essential to prevent respiratory and cardiac arrest. The first step is to perform needle decompression, which involves inserting a large-bore needle into the affected side of the chest to release the trapped air in the triangle of safety. After that, a chest tube is inserted to further drain the air and prevent the reoccurrence of a pneumothorax.

questions.text: What is the ideal time for nuchal translucency evaluation? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 11-14 weeks

 

Explanation

 

Nuchal Translucency (NT):

 

  • Definition: Nuchal translucency refers to the maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue overlying the fetal spine at the back of the neck.
  • Significance: An increased NT measurement is associated with an increased risk for fetal aneuploidy (such as Down syndrome) and various structural anomalies including cardiovascular defects, hydrops fetalis, and cystic hygroma.

 

Timing:

 

  • NT is measured between 11 weeks and 13 weeks 6 days (or 11-14 weeks) of gestation. This time frame is critical as it ensures the accuracy of the measurement and its correlation with potential anomalies.

 

Measurement Criteria:

 

  • Crown-Rump Length (CRL): Should be between 45-84 mm.
  • Fetal Position: Fetus should be in the mid-sagittal plane and in a neutral position.
  • Image Quality: The image must be magnified, and the widest space should be measured.
  • Caliper Placement: The ‘+’ calipers must be placed on the inner borders of the nuchal space, ensuring the amnion is seen separately.

 

Screening Efficiency:

 

  • NT Alone: Provides a 65% detection rate for Down syndrome.
  • Combined Test: When combined with the Dual Marker test (beta hCG and PAPP-A), the detection rate for Down syndrome improves to 80%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 6-8 weeks: This is too early for accurate NT measurement.

 

Option C. 14-16 weeks: This is beyond the optimal time frame for NT evaluation, reducing the effectiveness of the screening.

 

Option D. 16-20 weeks: This period is too late for NT measurement, which should be performed in the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal time for nuchal translucency evaluation is between 11-14 weeks of gestation.

 

 

Ref: Page no 860, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: To allay anxiety
To decrease secretions
For muscle relaxation

questions.text: A patient was schedule for surgery. Before giving anaesthesia, he was administered glycopyrrolate. What is rationale of giving glycopyrrolate before anaesthesia?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. To decrease secretions

 

  • Preanesthetic medication refers to the use of drugs before anaesthesia to make it safe and less unpleasant.
  • When inhalation anaesthetic agents are given, they inhibit the ciliary function resulting in accumulation of secretions in the respiratory pathway. Therefore anti-cholinergic drugs like atropine or glycopyrrolate are used as pre-anaesthetic medication for their anti-secretory action.
  • Glycopyrrolate is twice as potent and longer acting quaternary anti-muscarinic which does not produce central effects. Anti-secretory action is more marked than atropine and tachycardia is less marked. It acts rapidly when given i.v. and is the preferred anti-muscarinic in anaesthetic practice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To allay anxiety: Glycopyrrolate is not used to allay anxiety. Anxiolytics such as benzodiazepines are typically used for this purpose.

 

Option C. As inducing agent: Glycopyrrolate is not an inducing agent. Inducing agents are drugs like propofol or thiopental used to induce anaesthesia.

 

Option D. For muscle relaxation: Glycopyrrolate is not used for muscle relaxation. Muscle relaxants like vecuronium or succinylcholine are used for this purpose during surgical procedures.

 

Educational objective:

 

Glycopyrrolate is administered before anaesthesia to decrease respiratory secretions, making the anaesthetic procedure safer and more efficient by preventing the accumulation of secretions that can interfere with the airway during surgery.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/. 413,414

questions.text:
In which of the following situations will you use a sanitizer? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. Before examining the patient
  2. After examining the patient
  3. After touching the patient's surroundings
  4. Hands are visibly soiled
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, B and C only

 

Healthcare personnel should perform hand hygiene with soap and water when hands are visibly soiled.

 

Healthcare personnel should use an alcohol-based hand rub for the following clinical indications:

 

  • Immediately before touching a patient
  • Before performing an aseptic task (e.g., placing an indwelling device) or handling invasive medical devices
  • Before moving from work on a soiled body site to a clean body site on the same patient
  • After touching a patient or the patient’s immediate environment
  • After contact with blood, body fluids, or contaminated surfaces
  • Immediately after glove removal

 

Other Option:

 

D. Hands are visibly soiled: In this case, hand washing with soap and water is recommended rather than using a sanitizer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Healthcare personnel should use hand sanitizer before and after examining a patient and after touching the patient's surroundings. However, when hands are visibly soiled, hand hygiene should be performed using soap and water instead of a sanitizer.

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant

questions.text: A woman with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Which of the following is true? (NEET PF 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance

 

Explanation

 

This statement refers to the Inverse Square Law, which states that the intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source. This means that as the distance from the radiation source increases, the intensity of the radiation decreases exponentially. This law is fundamental in radiation physics and is crucial for understanding radiation exposure and protection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Small blood vessels are most radioresistant: This is incorrect. Larger vessels are more radioresistant compared to smaller ones. The endothelial cells lining small vessels are more susceptible to radiation damage due to their relatively higher rate of proliferation.

 

Option C. Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant: This is incorrect. Rapidly proliferating cells are the most radiosensitive. Cells that are dividing quickly, such as those in the gastrointestinal tract, bone marrow, and reproductive tissues, are more susceptible to radiation damage because radiation primarily affects DNA during cell division.

 

Option D. Small bowel is most radioresistant: This is incorrect. The gastrointestinal (GI) tract, including the small bowel, is among the most radiosensitive organ systems in the body. This high radiosensitivity is due to the rapid turnover of the epithelial cells lining the GI tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source, as described by the Inverse Square Law.

 

Ref: Page no 610, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: During development, thymic cells recognizing self-antigens are removed to prevent autoimmunity. Which gene among the following is involved in the process? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AIRE

 

The above process is called central tolerance and the AIRE (Autoimmune Regulator) protein is necessary for this process.

 

Immature self-reactive T and B lymphocyte clones recognize self-antigens during their maturation in the central lymphoid organs (thymus for T cells, bone marrow for B cells). They are killed or rendered harmless.

 

The removal of self-reacting T lymphocytes in the thymus is called negative selection/ deletion. A protein called AIRE (autoimmune regulator) stimulates expression of some “peripheral tissue-restricted” self-antigens in the thymus and is thus critical for deletion of immature T cells specific for these antigens. Mutations in the AIRE gene are the cause of an autoimmune polyendocrinopathy
